channel.title: Your awesome title
channel.description: Write an awesome description for your new site here. You can edit this line in _config.yml. It will appear in your document head meta (for Google search results) and in your feed.xml site description.

item.title: Welcome to Jekyll!
item.description:
You’ll find this post in your _posts directory. Go ahead and edit it and re-build the site to see your changes. You can rebuild the site in many different ways, but the most common way is to run jekyll serve, which launches a web server and auto-regenerates your site when a file is updated.

To add new posts, simply add a file in the _posts directory that follows the convention YYYY-MM-DD-name-of-post.ext and includes the necessary front matter. Take a look at the source for this post to get an idea about how it works.

Jekyll also offers powerful support for code snippets:

def print_hi(name)
  puts "Hi, #{name}"
end
print_hi('Tom')
#=> prints 'Hi, Tom' to STDOUT.

Check out the Jekyll docs for more info on how to get the most out of Jekyll. File all bugs/feature requests at Jekyll’s GitHub repo. If you have questions, you can ask them on Jekyll’s dedicated Help repository.

item.title: 3 Python Data Analysis C1
item.description:
<!DOCTYPE html>

Python Data Analysis C1
In [1]:
# Import packages 

%matplotlib inline

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
import os

os.chdir('/Users/kajtova/Spyder/Jupyter')
plt.style.use(os.path.join(os.getcwd(), 'mystyle.mplstyle'))
In [2]:
# Two dataframes exist in the example, ratings and movies. 
# Goal: check the distribution of rating of drama movies. Movies database has no information on the genre of the movie, instead the two dataframes can be matched through item id. 

column_names = [ 'user id', 'item id', 'rating', 'timestamp' ]

ratings = pd.read_csv( 'ratings.dat', sep = '::', index_col = False, names = column_names, encoding = "UTF-8", engine = 'python' )

# Preivew the data
ratings.head()
ratings.tail()
ratings[1:2]
ratings[:5]

# Calculate the frequency of ['rating'], sort the result and plot a bar:
ratings_counts = ratings['rating'].value_counts()
ratings_counts_sorted = ratings_counts.sort_index()
ratings_counts_sorted.plot.bar( color = 'Blue')
plt.title( 'Movie rating' )
plt.xlabel( 'Rating' )
plt.ylabel( 'Count' )
Out[2]:
<matplotlib.text.Text at 0x11ad0d198>
In [3]:
# Filtering data based on a condition
column_names = ['movies id', 'movie title', 'genre' ]

movies = pd.read_csv( 'movies.dat', sep = '::', names = column_names, index_col = False, encoding = 'UTF-8', engine = 'python' )

movies.head()

movies.genre.unique()
Out[3]:
array(['Documentary|Short', nan, 'Short|Horror', ...,
       'Documentary|Animation|Mystery', 'Comedy|Talk-Show',
       'Documentary|Crime|Sport'], dtype=object)
In [4]:
# Create new dataframe, which is a subset of the movies dataframe, conditional on the genre

movies_drama = movies[movies['genre'] == 'Crime|Drama' ]

movies_drama_row = movies_drama.shape[0] # gives number of row count
movies_drama_col = movies_drama.shape[1] # gives number of col count
print( movies_drama_row, movies_drama_col )

342 3
Out[4]:
15      2844
216    20859
230    21406
262    22286
265    22403
Name: movies id, dtype: int64
In [5]:
# Select only the ids form the drama movies, and based on these ids, check if they appear in the movies dataframe

movies_drama_id = movies_drama[ 'movies id' ]
movies_drama_id.head()

# Extract the ids in the ratings that correspond to drama movies
criterion = ratings['item id'].map( lambda x:( movies_drama_id == x ).any() ) 

ratings_drama = ratings[ criterion ]

#  Plot ratings for drama movies 
rating_counts = ratings_drama['rating'].value_counts()
sorted_counts = rating_counts.sort_index()
sorted_counts.plot( kind = 'bar', color = "SteelBlue" )
plt.title( 'Movie ratings for drama movies' )
plt.xlabel( 'Rating' )
plt.ylabel( 'Count' )
Out[5]:
<matplotlib.text.Text at 0x11aca0908>

item.title: 2 Install Jekyll And Solve Errors Along The way
item.description:
How to install jekyll

Open Terminal and type:

sudo gem install jekyll

You are prompted to input your password so the installation proceeds. If there is an error during the installation

ERROR:  Error installing jekyll:
    liquid requires Ruby version >= 2.1.0.

just install another version of jekyll

sudo gem install jekyll - 2.5

Once installation is done, check the version installed.

jekyll -v

Create new project with jekyll

To create a new project on your Desktop type:

cd Desktop/
jekyll new project
# New jekyll site installed in /Users/username/Desktop/project.

Continue with 

jekyll serve

Setting up Jekyll

Installing Jekyll is simple just by following these commands in the Terminal

sudo gem install jekyll
cd /Users/username/Desktop
jekyll new site
jekyll serve
# Then, open your browser and type localhost:4000.

However, below is a description of the installation process when multiple errors popped out. I go step by step to the solution and add more explanation to the above commands.

In Terminal type to install jekyll

sudo gem install jekyll

An error occured: 

ERROR:  Error installing jekyll:
    liquid requires Ruby version >= 2.1.0.

To solve this, install older version of Jekyll 2.5.0. as per the advice here. 

sudo gem install jekyll -v 2.5

Once installation is successfull, make sure you are working in desired directory. Setting up a new project on Desktop would go like this:

cd Desktop

If you are previewd that no directory exists, make sure you type the full path to the directory:

cd /Users/username/Desktop/

To create a new folder for jekyll on Desktop continue with the following: (my project is called site)

jekyll new site
cd site/
jekyll serve

In my case another error occured:

Configuration file: /Users/username/site/_config.yml
            Source: /Users/username/site
       Destination: /Users/username/site/_site
      Generating... 
  Liquid Exception: No header received back. in _posts/2017-08-02-welcome-to-jekyll.markdown

Following this advice I installed another gem (for the newbies: no need to know what is that in this step, the experienced should already know about it)

sudo gem install rouge
# rouge-2.1.1.gem (100%)
# Added highlighter: rogue in

Once installation of the gem rouge is done, open the project folder and add highlighter: rogue in the _config.yml file. Save the file and run the [jekyll serve] command again in the Terminal

jekyll serve

If your server starts running, you will see the last two lines as:

Server address: http://XXX.0.0.1:4000/
Server running... press ctrl-c to stop.

Last step is to just open your browser and type

localhost:4000

The local host number is shown in the server address.

You are good to go for now.

Open Jekyll

If you exit your browser opened with jekyll, stop the server and quit the Terminal, you can later open Jekyll again by navigating to the project in the Terminal and running it.

cd /Users/username/site/
jekyll serve

item.title: 1 Step 1 In Python
item.description:
Python 3.6.1

Download Python from the official web site. Once installation is done, open Terminal in your computer and type python. The output will provide an information of the version of Python available on your computer.

# Input
python

# Output
Last login: Mon Jul 21 02:47:17 on ttys000
XXXX-MBP:~ username$ python
Python 3.6.1 |Anaconda 4.4.0 (x86_64)| (default, May 11 2017, 13:04:09) 
[GCC 4.2.1 Compatible Apple LLVM 6.0 (clang-600.0.57)] on darwin
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>>

If you were previewed Python of 2.x version, check for the 3.x version by typing. The ouput should be similar as above. 

# Input
python3 --version

You can insert commands of code in the terminal, and everything you type will be executed there. As more user friendly ways exist to write your code, exit Python from the terminal.

# Input
quit()

# The result of the command will close **Python**.

Python GUI

IDLE

One way to start writing your code is to use the graphical interface of Python, which is called IDLE. You can access it in the folder where Python was installed in your computer. It comes by default with the installation. It is also called the Python Shell .

Spyder & Jupyter Notebook

More user friendly alternatives to IDLE are Spyder and Jupyter Notebook. To use either of the two, first you need to download Anaconda. Once done with the installation of Anacodna, open the Anaconda Navigator and then both the Spyder (Scientific Python Development Environment) app and Jupyter Notebook should be there to launch.

As for Anaconda, to see everything that comes with its installation, ask for the list in the Terminal:

# Input 
conda list

# Output
# packages in environment at /Users/username/anaconda:
_license                  1.1                      py36_1  
alabaster                 0.7.10                   py36_0  
anaconda                  4.4.0               np112py36_0  
anaconda-client           1.6.3                    py36_0  
anaconda-navigator        1.6.2                    py36_0

You will get an overview of all the packages/features/libraries downloaded with it, along with the corresponding version.

Spyder

The interface of Spyder is similar to the one of R. You have an editor where you type your code and you can execute it all at once, or line by line if you prefer. The code you type, once executed, will halt if encounters an error. The console displays the execution of your code. You can write a code directly in the console, but it will not be saved unless you write it in the editor and save it. If you have a third window in Spyder, just close it as the only windows you need for now are the Editor and the IPython console.

You can also open the IPython console through Terminal . The output is the same as the information you have in a new window of Ipython Console in Spyder. 

# Input
ipython

# Output
Python 3.6.1 |Anaconda 4.4.0 (x86_64)| (default, May 11 2017, 13:04:09) 
Type "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.

IPython 5.3.0 -- An enhanced Interactive Python.
?         -> Introduction and overview of IPython's features.
%quickref -> Quick reference.
help      -> Python's own help system.
object?   -> Details about 'object', use 'object??' for extra details.

Jupyter Notebook

Jupyter Notebook is another editor for Python. It is often preferred over Spyder since everything is previewed in one window, and additionally you can type markdown notes between your code to look like a notebook.

Open it through Anaconda navigator, by launching the application. A new tab will pop out in your browser and your Terminal will open automatically to establish a connection to a server on a local host (localhost:8888/tree). Open a new notebook via the New button, selecting the desired version of Python. The beuaty of it is that you can download your notebook in different reusable file types (Notebook .ipynb, Python .py, HTML .html, Markdown .md, reST .rst, LaTeX .tex, PDF via LaTeX .pdf).

Packages

To start writing code, first you need to be able to load libraries. Remember the libaries downloaded with Anaconda? You can use them in the Python editor, you just need to import them, or import only certain items from the library, when you don’t need all the features available. 

# Input
import nameofthelibary
import item from nameofthelibary

Alternatively, you can install a library through Terminal. When no error is privewed neither in the terminal nor in the console, then the library has been successfully installed. 

# Input
pip install numpy
# Output
Collecting numpy
  Using cached numpy-1.13.1-cp36-cp36m-macosx_10_6_intel.macosx_10_9_intel.macosx_10_9_x86_64.macosx_10_10_intel.macosx_10_10_x86_64.whl
Installing collected packages: numpy
Successfully installed numpy-1.13.1
